H1.1.claim: Pronoun patterns correlate with psychological states

H1.2.claim: Semantic networks vary across individuals and correlate with creativity

H1.3.claim: Semantic networks can be inferred from chat behavior
H1.3.gap: No direct studies; hypothesis to test empirically

H1.4.claim: Self-concept, values, and beliefs measurable from chat

H1.5.claim: Big Five personality traits can be inferred from chat patterns

H1.6.claim: Reasoning style differences are detectable from chat
H1.6.gap: No direct studies; hypothesis requiring empirical work

H1.7.claim: Embedding distances reflect cognitive semantic distance

H1.8.gap: Adaptation to shorter formats (INS-001 uses 5 vs. 10 words)

H2.1.claim: Chat data has ecological validity for cognitive patterns

H2.2.gap: Needs empirical demonstration in AI chat context

H2.3.claim: Cognitive phenotype measurements show acceptable test-retest reliability
H2.3.gap: Critical empirical question; no direct studies

H2.4.claim: Cognitive phenotypes generalize across AI platforms

H2.5.claim: Selection effects are systematic and adjustable

H2.6.claim: Task-based and naturalistic measures show convergent validity
H2.6.gap: No direct studies; requires empirical work
